description: What is real? How do we know what we know? What does it mean to be good? This course tackles the biggest questions in life, introducing you to the foundational ideas of the world's greatest thinkers.

lessons.title: What is Philosophy? Metaphysics and Epistemology
lessons.description: Define philosophy and explore its two core branches: Metaphysics (the study of reality) and Epistemology (the study of knowledge).

sections.content: Learning Objectives

items: Define philosophy as the love of wisdom and the study of fundamental questions
Identify the two core branches: Metaphysics and Epistemology
Understand the difference between philosophical and scientific questions

sections.content: The Love of Wisdom

Philosophy, from the Greek 'philosophia', literally means 'love of wisdom'. It is the systematic study of the most fundamental questions about existence, knowledge, values, reason, mind, and language. While science asks 'how' the universe works, philosophy often asks 'why' it works the way it does, or what it means for us.
The Two Foundational Branches

sections.alt: Diagram showing Metaphysics (galaxy icon) and Epistemology (human head with question mark)
sections.caption: The two core branches of philosophy

sections.content: **Metaphysics:** The study of the nature of reality. It asks: What is real? What is the relationship between mind and matter? Do we have free will?
**Epistemology:** The theory of knowledge. It asks: What does it mean to 'know' something? How do we acquire knowledge? Can we ever be certain?

sections.question: The branch of philosophy that studies the nature of reality is called...?
sections.explanation: Metaphysics deals with the fundamental nature of reality, while Epistemology deals with knowledge.

lessons.title: Logic and Argument
lessons.description: Learn the essential tools of philosophical reasoning: logic, deductive vs inductive arguments, and common logical fallacies.

sections.content: Learning Objectives

items: Define logic as the study of reasoning
Differentiate between deductive and inductive arguments

sections.content: The Toolbox of Philosophy

Logic is the essential tool that philosophers use to construct and evaluate arguments. An argument in philosophy isn't a heated dispute; it's a set of statements (premises) that are offered as reasons for another statement (the conclusion).

sections.alt: Diagram contrasting deductive reasoning (top-down) with inductive reasoning (bottom-up)
sections.caption: Two types of logical arguments

sections.content: **Deductive Arguments:** Aim to provide conclusive proof. If the premises are true, the conclusion MUST be true. Example: All men are mortal. Socrates is a man. Therefore, Socrates is mortal.
**Inductive Arguments:** Aim to provide probable support. The premises make the conclusion likely, but not guaranteed. Example: The sun has risen every day. Therefore, the sun will rise tomorrow.
Logical Fallacies
These are common errors in reasoning that weaken an argument. A famous example is the 'ad hominem' attack, which attacks the person making the argument instead of the argument itself.

sections.alt: Icon showing one person attacking another instead of their argument
sections.caption: Ad Hominem fallacy: attacking the person, not the argument

sections.question: An argument that aims for a guaranteed, certain conclusion is called...?
sections.explanation: Deductive arguments aim for certainty - if the premises are true, the conclusion must be true.

lessons.title: Plato and the World of Forms
lessons.description: Explore Plato's Theory of Forms and his famous Allegory of the Cave, foundational concepts in Western philosophy.

sections.content: Learning Objectives

items: Identify Plato as a foundational figure in Western philosophy
Understand the Allegory of the Cave

sections.content: The Theory of Forms

Plato believed that the physical world we perceive is not the real world; it is merely a shadow or imperfect copy of a higher, eternal reality called the World of Forms. For Plato, there is a perfect 'Form' of Justice, Beauty, and even a Chair.

sections.alt: Illustration showing a perfect, glowing Form of a chair casting a shadow as an imperfect physical chair
sections.caption: The perfect Form vs. the imperfect copy

sections.content: The Allegory of the Cave

Plato imagined prisoners chained in a cave, seeing only shadows on a wall, believing them to be reality. If one prisoner escapes, they see the true objects (the Forms) and the sun (the Form of the Good). The philosopher is like the escaped prisoner, seeking truth beyond mere appearances.

sections.alt: Symbolic diagram of Plato's Allegory of the Cave
sections.caption: From shadows to enlightenment

sections.question: In Plato's Allegory of the Cave, what do the shadows on the wall represent?
sections.explanation: The shadows represent the imperfect physical world, not the true reality of the Forms.

lessons.title: Aristotle and Empirical Observation
lessons.description: Discover how Aristotle diverged from his teacher Plato, focusing on empiricism and the concept of telos (purpose).

sections.content: Learning Objectives

items: Identify Aristotle as Plato's student who diverged from his ideas
Understand Aristotle's focus on empiricism and observation
Define the concept of 'telos' or purpose

sections.content: The World is Here and Now

While Plato looked to a higher world for truth, his student Aristotle was an empiricist, believing knowledge comes from observation and experience. He systematically studied the physical world, arguing that the 'form' of a thing was inherent within the object itself.

sections.alt: Illustration showing observation with a magnifying glass, representing empiricism
sections.caption: Knowledge through observation and experience

sections.content: Telos and Virtue Ethics

A core concept for Aristotle is 'telos', which means end or purpose. He believed everything has a purpose. The telos of an acorn is to become an oak tree. The telos of a human is to achieve 'eudaimonia'—flourishing—by cultivating virtues and living a life of reason.

sections.alt: Diagram showing an acorn transforming into an oak tree, representing telos
sections.caption: The acorn's purpose is to become an oak

sections.question: The belief that knowledge comes from observation and experience is called...?
sections.explanation: Empiricism emphasizes observation and experience as the source of knowledge, which was Aristotle's approach.

lessons.title: Ethics - What is the Right Thing to Do?
lessons.description: Explore the major frameworks of moral philosophy: Utilitarianism and Deontology, and learn how to apply them.

sections.content: Learning Objectives

items: Define ethics as the branch of philosophy concerning moral principles
Apply ethical frameworks to moral dilemmas

sections.content: Frameworks for Morality
Ethics, or moral philosophy, explores questions of right and wrong. Philosophers have developed several major frameworks to guide moral reasoning.

sections.alt: Diagram contrasting Utilitarianism (balancing scales) with Deontology (following rules)
sections.caption: Two major approaches to ethics

sections.content: **Utilitarianism:** A consequentialist theory stating the right action produces the greatest good for the greatest number. The consequences are what matter.
**Deontology:** Argues that actions are inherently right or wrong, regardless of consequences. Morality is based on duty and following universal rules.

sections.question: Which ethical theory focuses on the consequences of an action to determine if it's right?
sections.explanation: Utilitarianism evaluates the morality of actions based on their outcomes and consequences.

lessons.title: Existentialism - Freedom and Responsibility
lessons.description: Understand existentialist philosophy, Sartre's 'existence precedes essence', and the burden of radical freedom.

sections.content: Learning Objectives

items: Define existentialism as a philosophy of freedom and responsibility
Understand Sartre's concept that 'existence precedes essence'
Explore radical freedom and creating one's own meaning

sections.content: Existence Precedes Essence

Existentialism puts the individual at the center. Jean-Paul Sartre argued that for humans, 'existence precedes essence'. This means we are born without a pre-defined purpose. We simply exist first. It is then up to us, through our choices, to create our own 'essence'—our own meaning in a meaningless world.

sections.alt: Illustration showing a blank figure with question mark transforming into self-sculpted individual
sections.caption: We create our own essence through our choices

sections.content: Radical Freedom and Responsibility

This leads to 'radical freedom'. We are completely free to choose who we become. However, this freedom comes with a heavy burden of responsibility. We are responsible for everything we do and for creating our own values. This can cause 'existential angst', but it also makes human life uniquely meaningful.

sections.question: The idea that we are born without a pre-defined purpose is summarized by the phrase...
options: The greatest good for the greatest number
sections.explanation: This is Sartre's famous phrase indicating that we exist first, then define ourselves through our choices.
